author: sky.cactus
content: This is a high trust operation, as you need to trust that after the transaction the validator doesn't behave maliciously.

author: potuz
content: The validator can't behave maliciously in the queue. The flaw is in that you can't transfer the withdrawal credentials. So that's why I'm asking where is this offchain market that is supposed to exit. Not that I'm against the proposal it may make sense. For example if pools are extracting value from this, the protocol could extract that value. Just want to see if there is, in fact that value.

author: fradamt
content: Whether or not there is an offchain market, I think the value clearly exists, even more so if it was done trustlessly. There have been requests for this over the years. I don't know that anyone has ever worked out a complete proposal though, and it doesn't seem obvious (to me) what a good design would look like.

author: kinetickoala
content: Yes, currently it is a high trust operation enforced with "real world" contracts and such. I haven't checked recently, but cost was about 6% last time I did (may be more now that the queue has exploded).

author: sky.cactus
content: Hmm, good point.  I suppose once you are in the exit queue you could sell your position and the buyer is "safe".  I'm assuming the validator is exiting into a contract, not an EOA.

author: potuz
content: Yes, I don't oppose the idea, I just want to know about these markets if they exist

author: potuz
content: As for designs we can change the withdrawal request type to pass the fee as well. And we order them within chunks of epochs by fee or simply adjust the withdrawal epoch by a function of the fee

author: greystroke
content: Is the proposal here an EIP where there a marketplace that those in the exit/entry queues can sell their position in the queue for a market driven fee in some sort of trustless auction? Seems like a complicated upgrade, not sure it a good risk/benefit to implement.

author: potuz
content:
I have a dumb question (unrelated to the above). After ePBS introduces a 0x03 validator type.  What would be the feeling of allowing the stake of those validators be infinite, but not participating in any validation. That stake is just sitting capital that is there. Execution proposers are chosen at random from that slice of "builders", no need for fees, no need for payments, no free option problem at all. Anyone that is willing to stake enough ETH gets a chance to propose. 

We implement some circuit breaker mechanism if those validators aren't proposing (this is by definition a centralizing feature). This doesn't burn ETH as MEV-Burn would attempt, but this leads to large lockups so it benefits ETH the asset. It is technically very simple to implement, it removes any auction mechanics and communications between proposers and builders. It removes completely the free option problem. As long as there are more than a few differnet entities willing to stake there it should make multiple slot MEV more diffucult to attain. 

cc <@269786774660710400> you mentioned something like this to me a while back. What are the cons of this? Centralization of block building and multiple slot MEV are obvious ones. What others? I feel that a large FOCIL bwidth could help on the fiirst issue.

author: kinetickoala
content: No. Having a priority fee so that you can accelerate your position in the exit queue. I pay more to exit faster.

author: greystroke
content: Is it really a good system to let  validators pay a bribe to skip the line and therefore make the withdrawal queue less predictable for other stakers?
